title: Reorganize section 4 along the lines of slide 136 of the Prague meeting
body: ... as promised for yesterday (oops)

title: Accept target-resolves-against-anchor and add text that says so
body:
The new paragraph outlines differences between 5988 and 6690, wherever
that may finally go.

See-Also: https://github.com/core-wg/resource-directory/pull/56

title: Lookup: rt and parameters
body:
I think that rt is not an attribute of a registration; the first commit reflects that. (The second is more bycatch from that).

Possibly we can simplify the whole section; as everything in the result is links, we're only applying the same link filtering that 6690 already specifies (plus pagination).

title: removed read-reg, and changed lookup ep
Remove a redundant paragraph with its essentials
body:
The text was laregly redundant with the later descriptions of con and lt
query parameters, and somewhat contradicted the con part.

title: Small enhancements
body: Some minor text changes (commented per commit) I think are resonable and will merge soon unless someone speaks up against them.

title: ER, modelling semantics: Changes to the model itself
body:
This is the first step to closing [54], doing the changes to the model itself.

Won't close the issue by itself probably, as some other portions might mention the model.

This does not try to address any of the open issues.

[54]: https://github.com/core-wg/resource-directory/issues/54

title: 5988-vs-6690-anchors: Initial text for siding with 5988
body:
If the WG decides to use the clarified 5988 semantics for href resolution[1], then this is a starting text.

No attempts have been made here to clean up the terminology, this is only about the statements about what affects what, and is an update to the examples.

The last record in the example has been changed to be illustrative with the new behavior.

[1]: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/12u9QBS6q5v5IYknKl_bJYhJKrI

---

I'm phrasing this as a pull request so it is easily accessible to RD contributors; I don't expect this to be merged right away.

title: Action to be performed on another registeration request by the node
body:
https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-core-resource-directory-11#section-5.3

> A new registration may be created at any time to supersede
   an existing registration, replacing the registration parameters and
   links.

suppose a node sends another registeration request with any **New** core links , do we add those to its **RD** entry, as indicated by mentioning  `supersede`
Or do we **delete** the previous entry of node(resource) node from **RD** and create a **New** entry with its current payload links ?

title: ER: modelling link-format serialization vs. modelling semantics
body: Working with the ER model of `.well-known/core` in preparation of explanations around the use of anchor and href, I noticed that the model is something between a model of the link-format serializations and the web links data model. It uses much of the serialization's terminology ("anchor" and "href"), and refers to some cardinalities as they appear in the serialization (eg. anchor is 0-1 because it may be omitted), but at other places alludes to the data model (eg. rel has cardinality 0+, which reflects that a link can have several relations, but in the serialization they all get space-joint into 0-1 rel parameters). The model is now much closer to the serialization than the semantic model, and I think we should stay with that to keep the document from becoming too abstract. (Plus, I don't know which applications start breaking when we make `;rel=x;foo=bar,;rel=y;foo=baz` into `;rel="x y";foo=bar;foo=baz` which we could when we say the RD's data model is the abstract web linking model). Are we OK with the model reflecting the serialization and not the semantics? If if should reflect the serialization, the only discrepancies I spotted are that cardinality of rel and con are 0-1 (that count being low is probably another hint that it should stay this way).

title: Link model clarifications (mainly con=)
body:
This is the documenting text to the changes worked out first on the examples in #45.

It does not (yet) contain explaining overall text, but updates the various smaller mentions of the `con` parameter to fit together. It does change the semantics of using `con` on a registration update, but I believe that the previous wording was not what the original authors had intended. (Previously, an endpoint registering over TCP would need to explicitly repeat its con on every update).

title: Fixes for the idnits checker
body:
I've had to override the commit-time check for [idnits](https://tools.ietf.org/tools/idnits/) recently; these edits make the document idnits clean again.

I don't expect much controversy over those, but @petervanderstok, are you OK with labelling scheme://host:port as "con" in the diagram? (As it was, it's too wide for an RFC).

title: iana-registry: used in lookup?
body:
The "RD Parameters" subregistry is set up in the IANA considerations, but only referenced at the registration interface.

The lookup interface allows lookup by parameters of the same names (and page and count are exclusively used for lookup), but doesn't make a reference to the iana-registry.

Next steps (â†’CA): Add a reference to lookup interface description (and reviewing that text, decide on whether that does create linkage to any other existing registry).

title: Registration with plain cryptographic identity
body:
Currently, we prescribe that the registering endpoint needs to identify itself with at least an endpoint name, while we allow the RD to be configured to assign a domain based on its configuration.

We could allow the endpoint identifier to be absent as well, at least in principle (eg. make it a "SHOULD be set" but no syntactical requirement on its presence), and the RD's configuration then would need to set an endpoint name (like it can now do with a domain), or the RD would refuse the registration like it can now do for unauthenticated hosts. (The RD interface right now doesn't allow a 4.01 Unauthorized response, even though the security considerations indicate that that can happen.)

This would allow endpoints that have just enough persistent state to have their cryptographic identity in form of a PSK to register at the RD. Note that for those cases (and PSK seems not to be too uncommon in the CoRE security scenarios), the RD already needs to have received (or have a way to fetch) configuration about that key, which easily can contain a default (or the only permissible) endpoint name for that key.

I'd write a pull request to that respect unless controversial discussion about this starts here.

(This was fleshed out from in a discussion with Pekka Nikander during ACM ICN about very constrained devices).

title: clarified hosts and con relation for ER and 5.3.2
Group registration: identifcation of registered endpoints
body:
With the new EP and GP lookup link-format bodies (solving #21), the payload of a group creation has become odd: They are now the only place where a `<>;ep=...` can occur.

From how we express the model in link-format in other places, IMO the cleanest way of creating a group with members would be to address the members by their respective registration resources -- ie. if

~~~
POST /rd?ep=node1 â†’ Created /reg/11
POST /rd?ep=node2 â†’ Created /reg/12
~~~

then the group that contains both would be constructed with

~~~
POST /rd-group?gp=grp-of-some
</reg/11>,</reg/12>
~~~

which is consistent with group lookups, but requires a group manager that only knows the group members by their endpoint names to look them up first through the EP lookup interface.

The alternatives are to keep things as they are (and spell out that the hrefs are ignored and the ep= attributes are used like EP query attributes), or to come up with something that is not direct link-format at all (possibly `</rd-lookup?ep=node1>,</rd-lookup?et=some-type>` to create a group with all nodes of some-type and the node named node1).

My personal preferences are (in decreasing order) `</reg/11>,</reg/12>`, something-different and keep-as-is, but it's not a very strong preference.

title: [examples first] Do URI resolution via anchor instead of href
body:
These changes were talked about previously in Prague and allow preservation of link relationships.

A new example based on the relevant RFC6690 example shows different relevant cases (with `anchor=` present in the registration) in the lookup interface.

The latest suggestions of bringing the endpoint interface in line with that are not included yet.

title: document registration resource body semantics
body:
As mentioned in #41, the current concept of registration resources not semantically valid but being processed into semantically valid documents for the lookup interface is not clear from the introductory text.

Postponing a text suggestion until we know for sure how we want it to work.

title: Registration: drop lifetime "most recently supplied value re-use"
body:
The mechanism is useful in updates, but at the registration interface
they do not make sense.

Closes: https://github.com/core-wg/resource-directory/issues/33

title: anchor ambiguities
body:
With the normal directory queries, if the external  representation is 

</sensors/temp>;if="sensor",
 </sensors/light>;if="sensor"

Then a query of ?href="/sensors" would return all of the items.  On the
other hand if the external representation is

</temp>;if="sensor";anchor="/sensors",
< /light>;if="sensor";anchor="/sensors"

The same query would return nothing.

This behavior is leading me to some questions on how the context field
should be processed or ignored when doing filtering as part of the RD code.

Suppose you publish

Context="coap://example.org/sensors"

</temp>;if="sensor",
< /light>;if="sensor"


** Should a get with ?href="/sensors" against the path returned from the
post return any of the entries or should it find zero entries?  (Section
5.4.3 Read Endpoint links)

** Does the answer change if I do the query against the full resource
directory rather than a single subset of the RD? (Section 7)

Given that a response to a section 7 query would return

< coap://example.org/sensors/temp>;if="sensor",
< coap://example.org/sensors /light>;if="sensor"

** Should a query with ?href="/temp" return a response with one element - or
is the full context string needed for this type of query?  (i.e.
?href="coap://example.org/sensors*")

** I have already asked one question about anchors in the prior message, but
normalization for a response seems to be a problem here.

Jim

title: more con context
body:
Hi Jim,

Indeed, the text 5.3.4 can confuse people.
We have added an entity-relationship model to he draft that shows that context is an attribute of the registration.
Currently, all links of the registration resource share the same context.
Citing the context when comparing links in the same registration resource is superfluous.
I think that 5.3.1 should read about all links over all registration resources within an RD.

Text will be modified.

Thanks for pointing this out.

Peter

Jim Schaad schreef op 2017-08-31 06:55:
In reading through and working on implementing this draft, I have found what
appears to me to be conflicting language on the context parameter.

Section 5.3.4 indicates that context + target could have collisions and that
this is likely to occur if there are multiple configuration tools.  This
text appears to me to indicate that the context can be different for each
link in a registration resource.  Each update could provide a different
context.  (I will note that the text probably needs to discuss dealing with
both normalization of the context and building the full URI from the context
and target when doing the comparison.  The pairs
<coap://ep.example.com:5683, /foo/bar> and  <coap://ep.example.com/foo,
/bar> should probably compare as identical.

Section 5.4.1 in the third paragraph talks about updating the lifetime and
context in the same paragraph  Since I know that the lifetime is a parameter
of the registration resource, it is reasonable from the context to assume
that the context would also be a parameter of the registration resource
rather than of a link.

In my opinion, these are conflicting concepts of what the meaning of context
is.  Would it be possible to figure out which is supposed to be correct and
both let me know and update the document?

Jim

title: PATCH
body:
So, with this new understanding I am going to try some different questions
about PATCH.

1.  Is there a good reason to support the addition of new resources in two
different methods?  Addition of new resources can already be done through
the POST method, needing to recognize that the documents to be patched are
different is a potential error waiting to happen if this is not well
described in document.

2.  For the delete case, the patch string of {"href":null}  is more in line
with how I understand a JSON patch document to be designed.  The string of
{} would say that nothing is to be changed by default unless it is special
cased.  Setting the value of the href to absent or null would be easily
understood as saying remove the element.

3.  The text on patch needs to be clear on how to treat a patch document
where multiple occurrences of an attribute to modify occur in the patch
document.  It should also be clearer on the correct way to deal with
updating multiple occurrences of the attribute in the link document.  My
reading of the current text could end up with "</foo>;alpha=beta;alpha=beta"
as the output if the input was "</foo>;alpha=gamma;alpha=delta" and the
patch was {alpha:"beta"}.   I am not sure that is what you want to be
saying.

4.  This paragraph is missing some text I believe:

If the PATCH payload results in the modification of link target,
   context, or relation values, that is "href", "rel", or "anchor", the
   request SHOULD be rejected with a "Conflict" result code.

Why is this a SHOULD and not a MUST.  If you keep it as a MUST some guidance
on which rejections SHOULD occur and when they are acceptable would be
highly desirable.  Making it a MUST means that a Conflict response would not
be able to occur if I have my logic correct for anything other than an
addition request.

title: text section 3.1
body:
Hi Randy,

You are right, there are some hidden assumptions in 3.1.
Rephrasing seems the best way forward.

tanks,

Peter

Turner, Randy schreef op 2017-09-07 16:42:
Hi All,

There is text in section 3.1 "Principles" of the RD draft that saysâ€¦


   â€¦snipâ€¦"it follows that no information should be stored in the

   resource directory that cannot be discovered from querying the

   described device's /.well-known/core resource directly."

This seems counter to the text in section 1 "Introduction", which
saysâ€¦

â€¦snipâ€¦"These problems can be solved by employing an

   entity called a Resource Directory (RD), which hosts descriptions
of

   resources held on other servers, allowing lookups to be performed
for

   those resources."

Could the text in 3.1 be re-stated differently?

Randy

title: GET all registrations of /rd
body:
Hi Peter,

Sounds like we are basically on the same page.

In RFC6690 links, "href" always points to the target of the link, and "rel" describes the relationship between the parent resource that holds the link and the target resource. The other items are all attributes of the target resource.

So "con" refers to the registration resource, and reflects the "con" parameter that was supplied during registration.

Likewise, "ct" refers to the ct of the registration resource, that is the format that the registered links are returmed in. Anything that returns a payload has a ct.

Does it all make sense?

Best regards,

Michael


On Sep 8, 2017, at 2:46 AM, peter van der Stok <stokcons@xs4all.nl> wrote:

HI Michael,

For me it looks OK. A few reflections:
It must be clear in accompanying text, that "href" refers to the registration and "con" to the links of the registration. And core-rd.endpoint needs to be explained in text, and registered in core registry. Further, "ct" is an attribute of the links in all RD examples and not of the registration.

Cheerio,
Peter

Michael Koster schreef op 2017-09-08 10:08:
Hi Peter,
In your example, "loc" I presume is "location" which is how this is
returned in the response header when the registration resource is
created.
In my example, I propose a hyperlink to a resource, so "href" is the
usual key for this in a link JSON.
I also propose to include all of the link attributes including rt and
ct, so the client knows what it is without needing to infer anything.
So your example would look like this:
[
 {
   "href" : "/rd/541",
   "con": "coap://[fdfd::12]:17072",
   "ep": "example-endpoint-name",
   "et": "ocf-device",
   "rt": "core.rd-endpoint",
   "ct": 40,
   "lt": 600,
   "d": "floor-3"
 }
]
On Sep 8, 2017, at 12:25 AM, peter van der Stok <stokcons@xs4all.nl>
wrote:
Hi Michael,
I would have expected:
[
{
"con": "coap://[fdfd::12]:17072",
"loc" : "/rd/541",
"ep": "example-endpoint-name",
"et": "ocf-device",
"lt": 600,
"d": "floor-3"
}
]
and may be only ep and loc attributes;
With this information the rest of the link information can be
inferred.
cheerio,
Peter
Michael Koster schreef op 2017-09-05 20:37:
Hi Peter,
The representation on slide 4 is not a complete dump, but exactly
what
you say; it's the locations and the registration parameters, exposed
as link target attributes.
The example has one "self" link for the RD itself, and one link for
each registration resource (only one is shown).
[
{
"href": "/registration/",
"rel": "self",
"rt": "core.rd",
"ct": 40
},
{
"href": "/registration/f3cca57e/",
"con": "coap://[fdfd::12]:17072"
"rt": "core.rd-endpoint",
"ct": 40,
"ep": "example-endpoint-name",
"et": "ocf-device",
"lt": 600,
"d": "floor-3"
}
]
On Sep 4, 2017, at 11:37 PM, peter van der Stok <stokcons@xs4all.nl>
wrote:
Hi Michael,
Originally, I thought the same, but the packets get really large by
doing a complete dump.
The compromise is just sending the (endpoint names/ registration
resource location) with its registration attributes.
Peter
Michael Koster schreef op 2017-09-05 08:27:
I would propose returning links for all registration resources in
the
RD as shown in slide 4 of the attached deck (JSON format shown).
This
would include the most recent setting of the "lt" or lifetime
parameter as a link target attribute as shown.
On Sep 4, 2017, at 8:27 AM, Jim Schaad <ietf@augustcellars.com>
wrote:
Yes that is what I had in mind.  It would be useful to add a ttl
attribute
as well.
Jim
-----Original Message-----
From: peter van der Stok [mailto:stokcons@xs4all.nl]
Sent: Monday, September 4, 2017 1:46 AM
To: Jim Schaad <ietf@augustcellars.com>
Cc: draft-ietf-core-resource-directory@ietf.org; core@ietf.org
Subject: Re: draft-ietf-core-resource-directory = GET /rd
Hi Jim,
Personally, I like the idea.
That would mean that all registration resources are returned.
In the next version of the RD, location or endpoint identifies the
registration.
Uniqueness of links is specified in section 5.3.4, already commented
on by
you.
Your request means returning all locations with the ep, lt, d, and
et
attributes
and the associated scheme://authority:port value.
Correct?
Peter
Jim Schaad schreef op 2017-08-31 03:59:
I am wondering if there should be a GET action defined against the
resource directory object.  Currently, if an entity does a
registration for an endpoint it gets back a location for that
registration.  If a second entity modifies the endpoint and wants to
update the registration, it currently has no method to get the
location associated with the endpoint and cannot make a second new
registration since the <domain, endpoint> pair is required to be
unique.
Thus
Interaction: EP -> RD
Method: GET
URI Template: {+rd}{?ep,d}
Content-Format: application/link-format (or variants)
<rd/0099>;ep=endpoint1,<rd/0098>;ep=endpoint1;domain=beta, ...
Jim

title: multiple authorities per ep
body:
Jim Schaad schreef op 2017-09-06 00:14:
One of the issues that I just come up with, and might be part of an I
don't care space, is that if an endpoint has two different addresses
then the registration resource cannot have two different addresses
associated with it.  You cannot have two different registration
resources with the same endpoint name.  This means if I want to
register both IPv6 and IPv4 (or
other address types) with the same endpoint there is a problem.   I
also
just realized that same issue arises with schema.  These only apply if
you want to use the context parameter.  If you are going to supply
full URL addresses to resources then this is doable.  Given that the
context parameter is for space savings, I wonder if some method of
dealing with this should be considered.  Possibly defining some type
of context selector or something?

Jim

Indeed this is an issue that was also brought up by Dave Thaler, where he
referred to the multiple types of coap schemes that became possible.

For the moment, we made the model such that and extension to multiple
contexts is possible, but not yet supported by the RD, given that all
these
extensions are still under discussion,

Peter

One way that I have thought of dealing with this is to extend the check on
endpoint uniqueness from <domain, endpoint> to <domain, endpoint, context>.
The only downside that I can see is that it makes the query on the endpoint
resource slightly more complicated.

title: groups processing
body:
This is original comment by Jim, which have been restated partially by the issues before

I am going through the group processing and I have the following issues:

1.  There are no methods defined for modifying the contents of a group.
There is only a method for replacing the contents entirely.  Is this
intentional?

2.  The description of the context parameter looks to be a cut and paste
that you did not review.  If the parameter is absent, I do not believe that
it makes sense to try and infer a context.  My assumption is that a context
is only going to supplied in the event that a multicast address is
associated with the group.

3.  Similar to the request for a GET on the resource directory to get the
list of resource registries, I believe that you should have a GET on the
group directory to get the list of group registries.

title: lookup href, con contatenation, empty values
body:
2.  I am unclear if the context is what should be returned as the link
address for an endpoint or if it is just the scheme + authority (i.e.
omit
any path portion).

I find the concatenation of "con" and "href" values, as currently
suggested in
the examples, also difficult to understand.
IMO the href value should be returned between <> brackets, and the con as
an additional attribute.

I would find that logical, even if it makes the client side more difficult
to build the entire URI.

3.  For the domain and group lookups, is the href an empty string or
is it absent?  This does not make a different for the standard link
formation, but it does make a difference for the cbor and json
formats.

@ Michael can you answer, being involved in the link-json document


4.  I assume that the 'et' parameter should be returned on all end
points.
et can have no value; IMO do not return anything.

Do you mean, do not synthesis a value from the registration and add it?
That would be fine with me.

5.  How would an empty domain name be returned (this is my current
pre-configured default domain) - as an empty string or as just the
attribute name - i.e  d  or d="" ?

Actually the d= can have no value, and IMO like et, do not return anything
when there is no value.

title: Clarify processing of lifetime with new registration of already registered device
body:
According 

https://github.com/core-wg/resource-directory/blob/master/draft-ietf-core-resource-directory.md#registration-registration

> A new registration may be created at any time to supersede an existing registration, replacing the registration parameters and links.

and below

> lt := : Lifetime (optional). Lifetime of the registration in seconds. Range of 60-4294967295. If no lifetime is included in the initial registration, a default value of 86400 (24 hours) SHOULD be assumed. If the lt parameter is not included in a registration refresh or update operation, the most recently supplied value SHALL be re-used.

Therefore I'm not sure, if the explanation for the `lt` about the reuse of the most recently supplied value, just doesn't apply here (and may be moved to a more proper place), because this section is only about **new** or **replacing** registrations, or, if **refresh** or **update** registrations also apply to this section, somehow "extends" the behaviour of "replacing the registration parameters and links" (and may be therefore explicitly mentioned as exception in the "replacing the registration parameters and links, except the lifetime, where the below extra rule SHOULD be applied").

FMPOV, I don't see the use case, where a device sends a registration and the rd should use a previous lifetime without notice the device about that. The device would consider the default value, but, if the actual value would be smaller, the device will get unaware unregistered.

An example for "supersede" case would therefore be also a good idea, to clarify, what is intended.

title: Clarify text in 3.1
body:
There is text in section 3.1 â€œPrinciplesâ€ of the RD draft that saysâ€¦
 
   â€¦snipâ€¦â€it follows that no information should be stored in the

This seems counter to the text in section 1 â€œIntroductionâ€, which saysâ€¦
 
â€¦snipâ€¦â€These problems can be solved by employing an
   entity called a Resource Directory (RD), which hosts descriptions of
   resources held on other servers, allowing lookups to be performed for
   those resources.â€
 
Could the text in 3.1 be re-stated differently?

title: clarified text from ML
body:
atomicity idempotency, Jim
multiple query parameter, Fairhair

title: fixed typo: s/changed changed/changed/ in sec 5.4.1
body:
This PR fixes a simple typo.

Side question: I found a number of lines in the markdown document that have spaces before the newline character. Would a PR removing those also be of interest?

title: Add a "Principles" section
body: Contributes-To: https://github.com/core-wg/resource-directory/issues/24

title: Types of statements in the RD

milestone.description: Draft version to be submitted before IETF99

body: The lookup interfaces imply that there are four kinds of statements that can be queried from an RD: * res lookup `;ep=y;attr=z[;rel=a][;anchor=]`: There exists a resource /X relative to each address of endpoint y, which as attributes z. It is related to the endpoint or (if given) /B with a relationship a (defaulting to "hosts"). * ep lookup: There exists a host with some attributes (endpoint name, endpoint type) that is registered to the RD. It is a member of domains and groups as specified in arguments. * domain lookup: There exists a domain of a given name in the RD. * group lookup: There exists a group of a given name in the RD inside a particular domain. Are those the types of information obtainable from an RD? The text should be explicit about the semantics of what can be put in and learned from the RD, and not imply it by the way the lookup interfaces are described.

title: Principles

milestone.description: Draft version to be submitted before IETF99

body:
If we agree on some basic principles RD should follow, we can phrase them into a text that both guides other decisions in the RD design and can help implementers understand the basic ideas.

As I understand, those can be

* Statements obtained from the RD should stem from statements that can be found on the origin device (on .well-known/core or other ct=40 resources linked by it).

  As of -10, this is compatible but not enforced in resource links, and absent in statements about the whole device (where registration query parameters ep, et and d are exposed as resource attributes in the endpoint lookup)

  I'd treat commissioning tools that store information on behalf of the too-constrained origin node as an exception here. Another possible exception is the RD (or something interacting with it) making more statements true, eg. by registering the nodes's address in the DNS and thus making a resolvable (and possibly more stable) name available for use in con.

* An RD registration can only be updated using the registration resource (which typically only the origin device knows).

  If some entity (eg. a DNS-SD bridge) wants to update a resource's description (eg. change an instance name or rename an endpoint), they have to find (possibly through the RD) if and where the origin server allows such modification, and put the changes there.

Are those agreeable principles, and what else belongs in that category?

title: Example addresses
body: Proposed fix for #5

title: Domains as separate entities

milestone.description: Draft version to be submitted before IETF99

body:
(Summarizing a topic that came up in meetings and [on the list](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/jFjEaM0PYK72dq-i1lOLwuc9To4))

Based on the notion of the domains managed in an RD being fully independent of each other "like ships that pass in the night", the idea has been brought up to do away with the domain functionality at all and have the domains exposed as different RDs by the server that would otherwise host a single RD.

Pro:

* This would align better with the general web design
* Issues with the domain lookup interface would go away (#21)
* This would be consistent with the use of RD by OCF and LWM2M, where the domains are used to separate 

Con:

* This enforces the independence of domains; setups where endpoints know their ep= but not their d= could not rely on the RD to assign them to a domain (the default domain for the given endpoint) any more.
* RD discovery would become more complicated (What would it look like at all?)
* Domains could not spring into existence any more by virtue of a device or CT registering at it
* Lookups could not span multiple domains any more

title: Semantics of the <>;x=... syntax in group and domain lookup
body:
RFC5988 (web linking) describes that a statement of `<B>;C=D` in the context of A means that "A has a hosted resource at B, which has the attribute C=D" (with the implied "hosts" relationship from RFC6690).

The repeated entries of the pattern `<>;d="domain-name"` currently drafted for the domain lookup interface (and the analogous group lookups) are bear no such meaning, and all provide statements about the same resource.

In a way, they could be collapsed into `<>;d="domain1";d="domain2"` (or `d="domain1 domain2"`).

Given it then talks about the currently used resource-directory (that is `<>`), isn't that a more straightforward to express the desired information anyway?

title: Discovery through proxies
body:
Writing up #19, it occurred to me that short of static configuration, none of the discovery options are available to endpoints that are only connected through a forward proxy. (I'm currently thinking of endpoints running in browsers connected through coap+ws, or coap/ws, as I've recently taken to calling it).

Is there anything we can do to make the RD available to such clients? My first idea would be giving "the RD" an anycast name like draft-ietf-6tisch-minimal-security-02's `6tisch.arpa` hostname.

title: Discovery of the RD: Make sure we want all methods, and argue which should be used
body:
There are several ways specified for finding a host serving an RD:

* static (unicast or anycast, addresses or DNS? could contain full RD path (as in LWM2M)?)
* various neighbor discovery derived
  * RDAO
  * the border router (ABRO)
  * "other ND options that happen to point to servers (such as RDNSS)"
* might-be-defined DHCPv6 options
* multicast (all-coap-nodes + .well-known/core; serves the path by design)

There is an open issue to describe how this can be used with DNS-SD (#8), and it came up 2017-04-07 that discovery via mDNS by those mechanisms might be possible but is not advisable.

Can we give a set of discovery options that should be supported by all general-purpose clients and servers to avoid fragmentation where one vendor's clients expect an RDAO while the other vendor's server relies on clients doing a multicast?

Can we say anything about which options are recommended to use, and which are rather to be viewed as shortcuts in extremely constrained cases? Using RDNSS would be a candidate for such a statement. Maybe those cases are better described as "explicitly configured to use whichever RDNSS is announced", so this is something that's better than static configuration but still not to be expected from a generic client.

title: Add normative reference to RFC8132 (formerly core-etch)
body:
The document uses the PATCH request method and the 4.09 response codes
defined there.

Closes: https://github.com/core-wg/resource-directory/issues/3

title: Drop the `res` lookup parameter
body: This solves issue #16 ("nobody really knows what the parameter is for") by removing the parameter altogether.

title: What does "res" do as a lookup parameter?
body:
We are not clear on how to use "res"in a lookup query.

For example, what does xx represent in this query? 

    GET /example/rd-lookup-gp?res=xx

I couldn't find text to explain. Is it expected to be the address of a resource, like href or anchor+href ?

title: Is rd-lookup-* optional?
body: The text in section 7 says lookup is optional but the table in section 7 lists two mandatory lookup resource types. I can't find text to explain the difference.

title: lookup: Mention Observe for continuous interest
body:
Observe, ETag and possible future mechanisms are stated to be generally
usable, but phrased as a "like with any other resource", because there
is no need to actually define something new here.

title: Uniqueness scope for `ins`
body:
Within which scope should the `ins` parameter be unique?

The -09 draft (and the restoration PR #11) demands that it SHOULD be unique across all resources with the same `rt` and `d`. That is hard for the individual device to support out of the box short of adding its serial number to everything, and (given it's not a MUST) still insufficient for an RD exporter (eg. to DNS-SD) to use.

In the last meeting, labels for distinguishing two instances in a combined devices came up (two fridge compartments, `ins="upper"` and `ins="lower"`), which would violate that constraint when two fridges are present in one domain.

I'd suggest to either relax the uniqueness requirements and have whoever exports this to DNS-SD deal with the resulting ambiguities[1], or make them strict enough for ins= conflicts to fail early (an absent ins= would be such a conflict too, or is that a free pass to construct an `ins` at will?), and suggest a different mechanism for "upper"/"lower" distinctions (title?).

[1]: For example, as is done in the Z-Wave-IP, see design specification 4.1.2.3: "If several End Point Name and End Point Location entries are identical, the Z/IP RD MUST auto-append unique data to each of the conflicting End Point Names"

title: Drop "base URI" references
body:
All URIs of RD APIs are discovered standalone, and no relative URI or path-appending is required any more. Therefore, the term "Base URIs" and the distinction between "rd-lookup-base" and "lookup-type" in the RD lookup API are obsolete.

This has already been [mentioned on the mailing list](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/7zzSmZK6Od1Rw3vzpaenN4G6otw), and [acked by Peter](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/NCLNlY8N__TCf9UMEq5yF1WxSJs), if I understood his response correctly (which I'm unsure about, thus tagging this for review).

title: Restore ins=/exp=
body:
These commits restore the ins=/exp= definitions dropped after -09, and instead of referencing the DNS-SD mapping chapter, reference the (so far not even uploaded) RD-DNS-SD draft.

There is some confusion between where arguments can be used, but the "what goes where" of the link-format attributes is a separate issue to be tackled.

title: Add JSON or CBOR link format examples
body: As we support the alternative serializations from draft-ietf-core-links-json, I'd like to add at least the numbers in the RD lookup examples.

title: Add "ins" and "exp" link attributes
body:
"ins" (instance ID) is used to differentiate between two links which are otherwise indistinguishable. It is a text value which should be restricted to a maximum 63 octets.

"exp"is an attribute which provides a hint that the link may be exported to other RDs or other discovery services like DNS-SD

title: Describe finding an RD using DNS-SD
body: There should be a well defined way to find an RD using DNS-SD to find an RD. Needs assignment of a well-known record type/value and some text in RD to describe the use of DNS-SD.

title: How does a client get notifications of changes to a RD?
body: It would be good to provide a way for clients to receive notifications upon updates of an RD.

title: Registration update: (invalid) content format
body:
An update to a registrtion resource can happen with different content formats. Probably, 4.15 Unsupported Content Format should be added to the failure modes. (Or in general: How much of common CoAP practice needs to be prescribed for each interface?)

Especially: Is the absence of a content format admissible in the minimal (empty) registration update?

(May affect other interfaces as well.)

title: Review example addresses
body: Addresses should probably be formatted according to [RFC5952](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5952), and I'll need to look into the applicability of the 2001:db8: prefix reserved for documentation on whether addresses should be used from that area.

title: Editorial fixes from 2017-03-16
body: This pull request contains edits to resolve my comments [mailed to the list](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/7zzSmZK6Od1Rw3vzpaenN4G6otw) earlier; these here address the uncontroversial points [already acked by Peter](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/NCLNlY8N__TCf9UMEq5yF1WxSJs).

title: Add draft-ietf-core-etch as normative reference
body: This is needed for the 4.09 error code referenced.

title: Implied ports for con vs. ephemeral ports
body:
There has been confusion about the semantics of an absent `con=` in the presence of transient ports ([1](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/YmfB5VB1uZBrQlZhupgSuw4DXAg) first paragraphs, 5.3 HTTP example).

Proposed solution: more explicit wording about con= being practically required when transient ports are used.

title: Check with reverse-dependencies
body:
I'd like to check whether there are open issues in compatibility with documents that want to cite resource-directory:

* [x] [pubsub](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-core-coap-pubsub/)
* [x] [lwig-cellular](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-lwig-cellular/): just recommends the mechanism
* [x] [t2trg-rest-iot](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-keranen-t2trg-rest-iot/): just example use in 04; further use expected but nothing written down yet.
* [ ] [alternative-transports](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-silverajan-core-coap-protocol-negotiation/): initial issues addressed (eg. allowing full URIs in con=), check for latest status in progress
* [x] enumerate other users: done using https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-core-resource-directory/referencedby/ (informative references ignored)
